Widham Invitational - I broke 18:30 in the 5K!!! Really cool and fun race because I didn't know what to expect from myself because I hadn't raced in so long. I think the time really reflects my hard work over the Summer and I'm really happy with the result. The plan was for me, Luke and Adam to go out together and sit on the front pack but everyone went out hard so I decided to stay back about 50 meters from the front pack so I wouldn't burn out early like last year. I then passed like 10 people on the downhill, really letting my legs fly and caught up to Luke and we worked together for about a mile side by side catching up to a bunch of people. Eventually Luke ended up dropping back a couple seconds behind me towards the end which sucks because it would have been cool to finish the race kicking against each other, but I caught up to Adam and worked with him until the end. I ended up out kicking him (I basically started my kick pretty early because I suck at sprinting) and came in 5th place, 1st for Hall. I know Adam and Luke are itching to kick my ass next time so i've gotta watch out. I think it would be cool to get a bunch of guys next time to go out all together at Hall on Tuesday. Overall, great race. I know I couldn't have run as fast as I did without other people pushing me and without people to run with over the Summer. 👍

Alright so I said before in my log that I'm gonna try to make this one pretty long so here it goes... I just finished reading everyone's log (who logged) about the Wickham race today. I've started to really enjoy reading people's logs, especially after races, to see how it went for them. Each log is kind've like a story and its really fun to see them describe how their race went for them because I most likely didn't get to see them. First off, shout out to Chris Murray for spiking someone in the head after they fell in front of him. I don't know why I find this so funny but its just so stupid that he tried to jump over the guy but still skimmed his head (No offense Chris but that guy probs hates your guts rn). Also, shout out to Thomas Robinson for losing his shoe in the last 800 and continuing the race without it. Not gonna talk about that many other people's races because I'm sure you could just read their logs but I find it kind've sad that the tone overall seems a bit negative. It's the last race of the season and I was hoping everyone would run well, but I guess the combination of the mud, cold weather, etc... made it harder for people to course PR. Now onto my race. Beginning from last night, I had a shit ton of homework and only got like five hours of sleep and I'm not sure if this affected me or not but I was definitely tired during the day and slept for parts of English and Gov. I also tried to sleep a bit before the meet but Brandon Wolmer kept on bending down to sit on me and everytime I opened my eyes I just saw his ass so it was ridiculously hard to relax. Also, Naiwen kept on sticking grass in my mouth and started reading some of his English book to me. That part I actually liked it was a pretty good book and to be fair, Naiwen should be a guy that records Audiobooks, his voice is so soothing. Anyways, even though I was tired, I felt pretty decent before the race because the weather was cool and I hydrated a ton throughout the day and my pee was literally clear like wtf how does that even happen. When the gun went off I immediately tried to get in front of the pack because I didn't want to get stuck behind the mob of kids that I knew I was faster than. Thinking back on it now, I think that it was smart of me to go out hard at the beginning, but I probably could've eased off the pace a bit heading into the first hill and going through the mile mark a bit fast probably impacted the rest of my race negatively. In the moment though, it was more important to me to stay in the front pack of guys, which by the way was pretty cool because we were really packed up. I really do think the first uphill is a lot worse than the green monster because it's so gradual and painful. At least for me it hurts a lot more than the green monster. After the uphill our pack of like six guys narrowed out a bit more and I rolled down the downhill into the flat 800ish before the green monster. At that point there was one kid from another school and I think me, Austin, PK, James and idk who else but I know I was trailing those guys. I tried to make a little surge by PK but it was really unfortunate that he thought I was a southington guy apparently and bodied me back which really through me off for a bit there. I managed to recover though and I don't blame him at all for being physical, I probably would've too if someone came up on my shoulder like that. Like I said, it was just a bit unfortunate. From there I dropped back a bit and never really was able to recover back to those guys as PK started to really roll. I surged passed James on the green monster but he surged back by me at the top and I basically spent the rest of the race just keeping him in sight and trying to hang on. I'm not sure why, but at the top of uphills in races recently my arms have been getting really tired and from the top of the green monster, I wasn't really able to drive them as much after. I'm not sure if this is a form problem because I was focussing on the hill to drop my shoulders but maybe I should do a bit more strength training, idk. Near the finish line I really had nothing left, but I thought I was fine because when I looked over my left shoulder I couldn't see anyone close by. That was my crucial mistake because as soon as I looked back forward I saw the southington guy on my right, kicking right by me. I tried to recover but I was just so dead I couldn't beat him. Big oof. Anyways, I finished 6th and 4th for Hall and course PRed by like 4 seconds so I was satisfied with my result and I think it was a good way to end my season. Also, shout out for PK for taking the dub! He raced really well despite our little hiccup before the green monster. Looking back on my sophomore cross season, I think I ran really consistently and at least course PRed every race. My only race that was a let down was New Hampshire where I went out way too hard and couldn't recover. It's sad that it's over but I'm excited for captains speeches tomorrow and looking forward for indoor. I'm also really excited to race the mile time trial next week and hopefully break 5 to get that varsity jacket! Sam Makarawitz (I probably spelled his last name wrong) always puts his goal at the end of his logs so I think I might start doing that too, idk. I bet none of you actually made it to this point in the log, i've just kinda been typing and i don't really know how long it is, but if you have, shout out to you. I guess I'm gonna end it here and go to bed. I'm probably not gonna write a log this long for a while, maybe for the Armory idk. As always, chasing 17:30.

Wow, what a way to cap off my most milage week ever. This was the best I felt on a run since last cross country season. It's crazy to finally see the work I've been putting in pay off, that I can do 7 miles this comfortably again. I got a ton of sleep last night so I was able to fully recover from yesterday's long run which probably helped a lot with how I felt today. I finished with 6 strides, good stretching with my dad because he was feeling sore from his 3 mile run last weekend, and core. Also I saw Cabaret at Uconn which was very good. For whoever is reading this I would 10/10 recommend trying to sleep better even though it sucks to go to bed early over the summer, because it helps you recover so much better. I started wearing my pure cadences again because I've been doing hips a lot so I'm stronger and my IT band isn't hurting anymore and because my HOKAs were giving me bad blisters. Anyone got any advice for that because I still like the shoes? Maybe a custom insole? I'm going to go similar next week, but with hopefully a bit longer long run to get to 46-47ish, then hopefully into the 50s the week after.

Ok, so this log is going to be crazy crazy but nothing about running. So I was waiting for Thomas for night running at Hall with Zach S. and I found a locked bike lock on the ground. I started fiddling with it and said I was going to try to guess the combo. We started talking a bit then about combinations and he was like your not going to get it, it's like 1/10,000. So I guessed 0 0 0 0 and 1 2 3 4 and a bunch of other common ones and nothing worked. Then Zach suggested trying combos 1900 and up because they could be birth dates. So I went from 1900 and all the way up to 1969 and it just opened! The adrenaline rush I got from this was insane. Like in what world was I actually going to guess a locked bike lock's combo. Anyway, I kept it as a souvenir which is pretty epic.

I ran with Luke basically the whole race which was pretty cool. We got out together with a 5:17 first mile, which was a bit fast, and then worked the up hill and past a bunch of people. Then going into the second mile I think he dropped back a bit but was apparently just sitting on me because he passed me later. The third mile was where it hit me hard. I was doing so well beforehand and I know my splits were negative but I don't think too much. On that last uphill a lot of people passed me. I was around 20th at the start and dropped back to 34th for the finish. I was so locked in and exhausted but I remember that every once and a while I would hear some heavy breathing and I would think, is this Luke? Is this the end for my dream of being second for Hall? And then it wouldn't be. And I keep chugging along and I hear some more breathing and I think, OK this has got to be Luke, but its not. Then going into the final right turn before the woods and back into the field Luke comes up and we started working together again before he eventually passed me and I think, OK at least its not ADAM HANLON because I kept on telling him I was going to out kick him. Going into the final 300ish meters I hear heavy breathing and I think, OH NO! Adam slingshots around the turn and surges past me. I tried to go with him but to no avail. I'm such a bot and I know he's going to be making fun of me now forever. So 34th, in 17:30. Was it the time I was hoping for? No, but I'm trying to think positive that it just means there's a lot more room for improvement. I'm excited for Wave Mania where were going to cool down into New Jersey. Epic. Also congrats to the JV guys who are showing how deep we are, especially Jamie and Jake even though they're bots and missed the finish line. Congrats to the Freshmen who ran amazing for their first race of the season! We've got some pretty fast guys and I'm excited to see what they can do. Also for whoever is reading this we are fighting the Ender Dragon at 8:00 PM tonight on my minecraft server. The IP is 98.217.29.157:17303.

Knew I had a small cold the day before, but when I woke up my stomach was hurting and I was really nervous about the race. I slept through econ because we had a sub and I took a shit like 4 times and I felt OK towards the end of the day. Went out slower, I think I actually kept even splits for the race and put myself in a pretty good position. Was passing people for basically all of the second and third mile. Walker rolled me up on the green monster but I imagined the string coach was talking about and tried to reel him back in. Sopho and I both passed him at the tree but he caught up to me again and ended up beating me by like 10 seconds. The mud at the finishing stretch completely sapped my energy and I barely kicked, so many people passed me at the end which sucked. That being said, I don't really like to get down on a performance if I gave it my all and I did so I'm pretty happy. It was a really cool race and a great way to end the season, 10th in the state isn't bad but everyone better look out because were gonna be even better next year. Excited for time trials and the rest of the season going into indoor.

I thought that my sickness was gone and I just had the cough symptom left over so I went in to CCCs with the attitude of competing and doing everything I could to score. On the warmup for the 1k I felt sluggish and was coughing a shit ton still and when I got off the line my legs felt like dead weights and I just couldn't move them fast enough. I didn't go out fast enough. The plan was to go out at the front and run the fastest time I could, not caring about what anyone else was doing. I was pushed to the back at the start and even though Sam moved over a bit to let me by I wasn't able to work my way back to the front. Ultimately decided with Billing to still give the 3200 a shot later and I actually went through the mile very well in like 5:02 but everything went down hill from there until I fell into last I think and got lapped by like 3 people... I gave that one everything though so I can't really be too upset. I'm really proud of Adam, Thomas and Walker though for stepping up and scoring in the 3200. Crazy stuff, they all ran great. I wish I could have contributed more to winning the CCC west but oh well, good job to everyone else who scored points. Time to get better and sleep a ton. Like Billing likes to scream at me while I'm racing, I'm ready to give 'EVERYTHING' at States.

I felt great also, I felt like I was zooming for the first few laps and then looked down at my watch expecting to see a sub 5 split and saw 5:23. I think the big take away is that times aren't going to come out of nowhere... apparently I actually have to put the work in first. Ill be continuing my training so that when it really matters Ill be ready to PRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRR.

*Time Trial* 2.2 Miles in 12:32. 5:41 per mile.

Out the door at around 8:30, up to res 6 for a time trial from gate to gate on the trail. From the moment I started I knew I was in for a rough ride... I think I forgot how painful racing can be, I got a few interesting looks as I was huffing and puffing down the trail. First mile was 5:24 which is ok I guess, but then I just died, no other way to say it, finished with the tank on empty. Split 6:10 for the second mile which is just shocking and then chugged out the last .2 which is uphill. For context, I split a 6:10 mile at the end of my 13 mile long run last sunday...

Why did I race so poorly? Well, there could be a number of reasons. For one it was really hot today and I haven't raced in the heat in a whileeeeeee. Its all possible I didn't drink enough water, or I didn't get enough sleep, or the fact that I wore trainers not spikes and I didn't have a lot of traction. All of these are pretty much excuses though, the main reason is that I've been slacking off for this training cycle. I didn't build up mileage to as high as I wanted to, I didn't do core, hips, strength consistently, and my motivation to run has been slowly declining. A lot of that is because I was only allowed to run really early in the morning and it was so easy to come up with a thousand reasons laying in my bed to not get up and to just sleep in. Theres good news for that now, I'm allowed to run later again! Another thing is that I'm just not all that talented so I really do need a solid foundation to preform at my best.

So I'm gonna take a week off from running now, its more of a mental break than physical, and then get psyched to start training hard again throughout the summer. My goal is to be consistent with everything, to do everything I know I should be doing to get as fast as I can for the fall. Gonna get to high mileage, like Sam Frank high mileage and get into crazy good shape.

Also as soon as Im allowed to I'm going to start playing tennis again. It sucks that I missed a whole season and I haven't played in soooooooo long. The plan before the coronavirus was to work all summer at Hartford Tennis Club which was basically a dream job for me, I've wanted to work there since I did a camp there like 5 years ago. But now I'm not allowed to and even if I was I'm pretty sure they hired other people to replace me since I wasn't able to work.

However, I'm still optimistic that later in the Summer and the beginning of next school year I'll be allowed to work there. And even before that I'm optimistic that I'll be able to play tennis with a friend at the hall courts sometimes soon. I'm also optimistic that I'll be allowed to run with someone else soon or my dad will bike next to me on some of my runs because it gets a bit boring sometimes.

Point is, lots of great things to come and I'm excited to start working hard again. Don't expect anyone to read all of this, this is mainly just something for myself. I'll be logging again on r2w in a week.

Pushed to 9 to see where my fitness was compared to splits at the beginning of the xc season. I'm definitely less fit. Then on the cool down my calf started hurting, the same thing that I had during the season. I feel like I've been pretty stupid, this was so avoidable. Why am I doing hard workouts and building up mileage at the same time, I've never done that. Completely on me. Too much stress and my body couldn't handle it. Hoping this isn't a huge setback, but last time it took me out for a couple weeks. Not going to run until the pain goes away.

No pain but yes tightness and soreness in calves :(

Watched some videos on youtube from a sports rehabilitation specialist and he explained that your calves naturally get stronger while running, but if you increase mileage and stresses too quickly then you can overwhelm the calves before they're ready for the load.

This definitely holds true for me, usually at the beginning of my training blocks my calves get crazy sore and I usually just ignore it, stretch and roll, and it goes away after a while, probably because my calves naturally strengthen from running. I think my calves were really sore today because I did a bunch of calf raises yesterday, which makes complete sense.

I also got some good exercises from the guy on youtube to help strengthen calves because mine are obviously very weak. He also said hip exercises are good, which I do anyway, but I haven't been doing glute stuff that much and apparently that's good also.

So my plan is to stay at low mileage while doing all these good extra things until my calves aren't sore on my runs and then I'll start increasing mileage again. The guy said to take sore calves as your body's warning that it's probably not a good idea to stress them any more than necessary, so that's exactly what I'm going to do.

Edit: holy shit this guy on youtube knows everything. I was feeling around the achilles and it wasn't very sore. The guy on youtube said there were two types of achilles tendinopathies, one is insertional which is closer to the heel. So then I felt lower very close to the heel and it is very tender there. Then he explained something I don't really understand but apparently calf raises only help mid portion achilles tendinopathy and they actually worsen insertional achilles tendinopathy which is what I have. Anyways, I find it really dumb that I've been doing so many calf raises on stairs because that's what he told me to do to help strenghten my calves and just now im learning out that they can actaully be bad for my achilles. Now hes telling me to do calf raises but on the ground without the lowering part.

1600 Time Trial: 4:47.7

Decided to do a 1600 today and a 3200 with Everett pacing on Tuesday. I felt good and I think I pushed myself pretty hard, but in the end I ran a not so impressive time, about 11 seconds off my pr... I think it just proves that I'm not a talented guy, I can't just rebound from a bad injury and run fast 7 weeks later, I need lots of consistent, hard training to be at my best. When I ran 4:36 it was coming off of the best weeks of training of my life. If you go back to that summer conditioning, what I was doing was crazy and I wanted to go back to that kind of training this block so I could reproduce what I had done early cross. Then I made a bunch of dumb mistakes and got injured a couple times, so I'm living with the results. I'm going have to make a decision soon about college and part of that is going to be if I want to give myself some more shots at running fast. I don't feel like I'm done with this sport yet.

I'm back! Here are my goals for the summer, gotta hold myself accountable:

1. Get my ankle healthy
2. Stay healthy and stay uninjured
3. Get into the best shape of my life.
4. Make the CMU XC team.

I feel like if 1, 2, and 3 happen then 4 probably will, but if 1, 2, and 3 happen and 4 doesn't then I can't blame myself. I'm so excited to put in the work!
